record.title: Arcadia School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall that was the School of Arts from 1932 until the trustees gave it to Hornsby Council in 1981.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Arncliffe School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall run for many years by the School of Arts, and later by Rockdale Council.

23 Barden St (corner Stanley St), Arncliffe Still called Arncliffe School of Arts, SMH, 21 May 1953, venue for Coronation Ball, 11 May 1951 change of ownership gazetted: School's trustees handed it over to the Rockdale Municipal Council. Council renovated and reopened it as the Coronation and Elizabeth Halls. Today still operated by Council as a community centre

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Ashfield School of Arts hall Holden Street (Building)
record.detail: Ashfield School of Arts hall Holden Street
Hall built as the School of Arts, but used as Ashfield Hall after the School failed to make loan payments, and later owned by the Baptist Church until demolition in 1936.

Cnr Holden Street and Liverpool Road First Ashfield School of Arts cnr Holden St and Liverpool Road, built 1888, Trustees could not make payments, building operated as Ashfield Hall till 1905, when purchased by the Baptist Church. Demolished in 1936

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Blacktown School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built on land donated by Charlotte Augusta Bowman, and licensed for public entertainment in 1910. It served the community as the School of Arts until Blacktown Council took over in 1960, when the building was demolished.

75 Main Street, Blacktown Land donated 1900 by Charlotte Augusta Bowman of Muswellbrook. Her family the Pearces were prominent in local affairs. Weatherboard bldg, iron roof, hall with stage, capacity for 400 seated people, but as many as 1000 turned out for popular events, floor 'specially adapted for dancing purposes', club room / amusement room, large room underneath, offices, porch in front. Hall officially licensed for entertainment on 22 Feb 1910 - this meant it could admit members of public, hold public entertainments eg concerts and film screenings. Blacktown Council took ownership of hall 1960, it was demolished in August 1960.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Leichhardt School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall, originally called Leichhardt Workingmen’s Institute, which housed a library and reading room, card room and six-table billiard room.
1A Marion St Leichhardt Report in 1921 says Institute had a library, reading room, card room and a six-table billiard room. In 1912 had 215 members and a library of 2300 books.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Ashfield School of Arts hall Liverpool Road (Building)
record.detail: Ashfield School of Arts hall Liverpool Road
The second Ashfield School of Arts hall, later given to the Exodus Foundation for an education centre.
162 Liverpool Road Ashfield Second Ashfield School of Arts built 1913 at 162 Liverpool Road Ashfield. Building given to Exodus Foundation 2006, reopened after renovations 2009

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Balmain School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall run by the Workingmen's Institute or School of Arts and completed in 1896, it included a 400-seat auditorium, a reading room and large lending library, a six-table billiard room and numerous smoking, card, meetings and class rooms.

332 Darling St Balmain Own building commenced 1887, completed 1896. Consisted of a 400-seat auditorium, a reading room and large lending library, a six-table billiard room, numerous smoking, card, meetings and class rooms.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Bexley School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall opened in November 1924, designed in the bungalow style of neighbouring houses, which is heritage listed and still in use as a School of Arts.

476 Forest Road Bexley Nov 1924, building officially opened by T.J. Ley, the local MLA and then NSW Minister for Justice, later convicted of murder. Brick and tile building designed in the bungalow style of the neighbouring houses. 4 rooms in all; large hall operated for a long time as a Billiard Room. Still has painted directory boards listing the names and dates of bodies that have regularly used the premises for their meetings. Heritage listed, restored 1986? Under National estate grants program.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Bondi-Waverley School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built with a strong Classical influence between 1890 and 1915 and still in community use.

138 Bondi Road, Bondi Heritage Branch http://www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_01_2.cfm?itemid=2620060 gives construction years 1890-1915. Notes earlier Waverley School of Arts operating in the 1850s.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Botany School of Arts-Literary Institute (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built by the School of Arts in 1867 and used by Botany Council for its first meeting in 1888. It was leased to Botany Council in 1959 and became the John Brotchie Memorial Nursery School.
1361 Botany Road Botany Building leased to council for Nursery School 1959, John Brotchie Memorial Nursery School since 1959

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Burwood School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built in 1879 on land donated by Thomas Walker of Yaralla, and extended in 1885. Purchased in 1936 by the Department of Education.

5 Conder Street, Burwood The School of Arts was built in 1879 and was used as a cultural centre. The land was donated by Thomas Walker of Yarralla and the building was designed by J.B. Elphinstone. In 1885 extensions were designed by David Ross and were built. This building served many fucntionas, early council meetings, religious services, reading room, games room, musical soceity performations, dances and public functions. In 1936 the Department of education purchased the building.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Camden School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall opened in 1866, and used for nearly a century before being turned into Camden Library in 1963.
40 John St Camden First opened in 1866, altered and turned into Camden Library 1963

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Campbelltown School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built as a war memorial, and at one time used as Campbelltown Council Chambers, demolished in 1976.
Cnr Lithgow Street and Queen Street Campbelltown Campbelltown Soldiers Memorial School of Arts building, demolished in 1967

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Carlton School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall in Carlton, still operating as a school of arts in 2009.
2 Short Street Carlton (13 Argyle St?) Built in 1900 as a private dance hall, http://www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_01_2.cfm?itemid=2330147

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Epping School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall constructed in three stages between 1906 and 1916, and opened in October 1909, the building was used for Baptist church services and is now Epping Community Centre.

9 Oxford Street Epping Constructed in three states between 1906 and 1916, opened in October 1909, now Epping Community Centre. Baptist Church services held there, 1930-http://www.hornsby.nsw.gov.au/servicesfacilities/index.cfm?NavigationID=1253

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Galston School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built for the School of Arts, later the Galston Community Centre.
37 Arcadia Road, Galston Built in 1892, now Galston Community Centre

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Glebe School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall and library built for the Glebe School of Arts, transferred to Sydney City Council in 1955 and used as the Glebe library for some years.

191-195 Bridge Road Glebe Had a lending library, a reading room, a lecture hall, a couple of class / meeting rooms and a six-table billiard room. In 1912 had 320 members and a library of 2543 books. 1955 the land and property of the Glebe School of Arts and Literary Institute placed under the trusteeship of Council. Building, furntiture and equipment and books cost Council £8087. Council converted premises for use as the Glebe Branch of the City of Sydney Public Library, opening Sept 1956.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Granville School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall, built on land donated by James Niblett, used by the School of Arts, as council chambers before the town hall was built, and later for technical education classes.

12 Good Street Granville Foundation stone laid 3 November 1883 and opened 4 June 1884. School of Arts was Granville Council’s meeting place and office from 1885 to 1889 when the Town Hall in Carlton Street was opened. First local technical classes held there in October 1884, continued to be used for technical education until the Granville Technical College opened 1910. Extensively renovated 2000. School of Arts sold 2006

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Guildford Soldiers Memorial School of Arts (Building)
record.detail: Guildford Soldiers Memorial School of Arts
Community hall constructed in stages 1901-25 and renamed and dedicated as a war memorial in 1933.
1 Calliope Street Guildford, cnr Military Road Building constructed 1901-25, renamed and War memorial dedicated 3 June 1933

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Haberfield School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall used by the School of Arts, and later as a dancing school, before Ashfield Council took it over in 1964.
78-80 Dalhousie St Haberfield Designed by J Spencer-Stansfield, built by J Dean of Petersham. Used as dancing school 1930s, ownership transferred to Ashfield council 1964

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Harbord Literary Institute hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built in 1918, with a later building constructed 1926-50.
cnr Lawrence and Oliver Street Freshwater NSW original building constructed 1918, later building constructed 1926-50

record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Hurstville School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall used by the School of Arts, which took over the Hurstville Council library in 1920.
Cnr of Cross Street and Crofts Avenue Received Council book collection in 1920

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Ingleburn School of Arts building (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built by the School of Arts and maintained by Campbelltown Council since 1960.
72 Oxford Road Ingleburn Campbelltown City Council has maintained the building and land since 1960, now Ingleburn Community Hall

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Lane Cove War Memorial School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Lane Cove War Memorial School of Arts hall
Community hall used by the School of Arts, but given to local council in the 1950s and later used as a library and senior citizens centre.
180 Longueville Road Lane Cove Building built 1923 as Lane Cove War Memorial School of Arts. Given to Council in 1950s as a public library, later Senior Citizens Centre.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Leura Literary Institute building (Building)
record.detail: Home to the Leura Literary Institute in 1915, the building later became a bed and breakfast hotel.
151-153 Megalong St Leura Home to the Leura Literary Institute in 1915, now a B&B

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Liverpool Memorial School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Liverpool Memorial School of Arts hall
Community hall used by the School of Arts but given to Liverpool Council. A painting from the school's collection was given to the National Gallery in 1963.
306 Macquarie St Liverpool New building constructed 1924. Painting from Liverpool Memorial School of Arts given to Aust National Gallery in 1963

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Manly Literary Institute building (Building)
record.detail: Opened by Governor Chelmsford in 1909, this community hall houses early classes for Manly Public School, and was eventually sold to the Department of Education. In 2009 it is leased by Manly Council.

12 Wentworth Street Manly Opened by Governor Chelmsford, 1909, Manly Public School classes held there for some time. Now Manly community centre. Owned by Department of Education, and leased back to Council.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Merrylands School of Arts building (Building)
record.detail: Community hall built 1917-25 with the help of Premier Jack Lang. It was transferred to Holroyd Council in 1982 and later used as a youth centre.

289 Merrylands Road, Merrylands, "Constructed 1917-1925, Premier Jack Lang instrumental in its establishment, currently used as Merrylands Youth Centre, transferred to Holroyd council in 1982, Youth centre since 1985 "

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Newtown School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall designed by E Williams, that featured a large library with its own street entrance, a big lecture hall, a six-table billiard room, various smaller reading, retiring, smoking, games, meeting and classrooms.

5 Eliza Street, Newtown Designed by E. Williams. Featured a large library with its own street entrance, a big lecture hall, a six-table billiard room, various smaller reading, retiring, smoking, games, meeting and classrooms.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: North Ryde School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: North Ryde School of Arts hall
Built on land donated by William Cox, the old School of Arts hall housed dances, meetings, fetes, exhibitions and a library. After its demolition in 1980 a new Community Centre and Library was built.

201 Coxs Road North Ryde The North Ryde School of Arts and Literary Institute, built in 1901 on land donated by William Cox of Pomona, became the venue for the Annual Ball, community meetings, fetes, art exhibitions, dances, physical culture and the like. Extensions were built in 1907. The North Ryde Library Branch was also located within. The original building was demolished in 1980 and a new Community Centre, School of Arts and Library complex was built.'

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Oatley School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Community hall that housed a billiards room, and served as church, school and centre for relief aid during influenza epidemic 1919. Building later housed a preschool and was given to Kogarah Council in the late 1960s. Additions have housed a baby health centre and municipal library.

26 Letitia St Oatley Wooden building, with hall, library, piano. In 1909 a billiards room was added. First Church of England, Methodist and Catholic Church Services held there. 1917-1921 served as classrooms of the first Oatley public school. Local centre for relief aid during the flu epidemic of 1919. Screened first locally shown movies. The only public meeting place until the Masonic Hall was built in 1922. In the 1960s a preschool operated in the School's hall. Hard to see the original School's premises today as it's hidden under later additions. Property transferred to Kogarah Municipal Council c. late 60s. 1969 a Baby Health Centre opened in red brick building in front of main hall. In 1971 the Oatley Branch of the Kogarah Municipal Library established in School's premises

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Peakhurst School of Arts and Public Hall (Building)
record.detail: Peakhurst School of Arts and Public Hall
Opened on Empire Day, 24 May 1909, this community hall held regular Wednesday night social dances and is still in use as a School of Arts and public hall.

691 Forest Road (near corner Bonds Road) Peakhurst Formal opening on Empire Day, 24 May 1909, speeches from State and Federal MPs, including local state MP Varney Parkes son of Henry. Regular Wednesday night social dances. School of Arts organisation formed June 1909 - ie. after the opening of the premises. Still in use as a School of Arts and Public Hall

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Penrith School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: 3 Castlereagh St Penrith Built 1909, opened December 1910,

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Prospect School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Wooden community hall built by the School of Arts and used to show films from 1950-58. It was transferred to Blacktown Council in 1967 and burned down c1969.
23 Tarlington Place Small wooden building, films shown from 1950-58. Transferred to Blacktown Council 1967, burned down c1969.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Richmond School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Opened by Colonial Secretary Henry Parkes in 1866, the School of Arts housed a library, theatre, and billiard room, and showed films. Council meetings were held there until 1913. Still used by community groups.

26 West Market St, cnr March Street Foundation stone laid 10 Jan 1866, hall officially opened by Premier Sir Henry Parkes 27 Aug 1866. After formation of Richmond Borough Council in 1872, the School of Arts was used for Council meetings until 1913. Library and reading room opened 1878. Extensions completed 1896 including new stage and dressing room. Billiard room built 1900, extended 1914. Electric light installed 1915. Regular showing of motion pictures from 1927. In the 1930s library contained 3000 books. Used as storage by RAAF during WWII. Library closed 1957 (after extension of municipal library service ). Demise of billiard room and sale of tables in 1950s. Has housed the Richmond Players since 1952 and the Hawkesbury Valley Lapidary Club since late 1960s. Heritage order placed on bldg 1981, National Estate registration 1984. Murray Wing constructed 2000.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Rooty Hill School of Arts hall (Building)
record.detail: Rooty Hill School of Arts hall
Community hall where the first Blacktown Council meeting was held in 1906, and still in use as a polling place.
32 Rooty Hill South, Rooty Hill Still used as a polling place, built 1902, first Blacktown Council meeting held there 1906

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Sans Souci Literary Institute hall (Building)
record.detail: Community building with a library, meeting room, kitchen, office and two small halls, where Housie and dances were held and billiards played. The hall is still used by many community groups.

107 Ramsgate Rd (corner Macdonald Street) Ramsgate Building consists of two smallish halls, a library, a class / meeting room, a kitchen, an office. Library was very popular; billiard room busy, Housie games and evening dances. At its peak the Institute had 880 members. Library now closed, billiard tables gone. But still in good shape, used by many community groups.

record.title: Sydney Mechanics' School of Arts
record.detail: Founded in 1833 on the model of Scottish Mechanics' Institutes, the SMSA sought to provide further education for working men through lectures, classes and a library. Many of Sydney's foremost intellectuals, inventors and innovators were associated with it, and it influenced the development of both the University of Sydney and technical education in New South Wales. It still provides a library and lectures to Sydneysiders in 2009.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Schools of Arts buildings
record.detail: A selection of Schools of Arts buildings showing locations and time of construction.

record.title: Sydney Mechanics' School of Arts (Organisation)
record.detail: The oldest School of Arts in Sydney was founded to provide further education for working people and has done so since its inception in 1833.

record.title: The School of Arts movement
record.detail: During the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, about 140 schools of arts or mechanics' institutes were established in Sydney by volunteers. They were independent community organisations, assisted by a small government subsidy, and they thrived as centres of local community life. Today, their legacy in Sydney is more than just the surviving buildings. Out of these humble voluntary operations developed the local public library, the modern community or neighbourhood centre, and formal systems of adult and technical education.
This is version 1. If the article is revised following peer review for Sydney Journal, the revised version will be uploaded. EG 26-07-2010
